### A concrete case study: **Poliomyelitis (polio) in the United States**

| Aspect | Situation **before** the oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV) and inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) were introduced | Situation **after** the childhood‑polio vaccine program was implemented |
|--------|------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|
| **Year the vaccine became routine** | 1955 – **Salk IPV** introduced; 1961 – **Sabin OPV** added to the schedule (both given to children). | 1970s‑1980s – two‑dose IPV (or OPV) schedule for all infants; booster doses added later. |
| **Annual reported paralytic cases (U.S.)** | **≈ 2 000–3 000** cases per year in the early‑1950s; peak of **2 400** in 1952. | **0–2** cases per year since 1979; **0** cases reported in 2020‑2024 (the most recent 5‑year period). |
| **Incidence per 100 000 children** | ~ 15–20 cases/100 000 (children < 5 yr) in the early 1950s. | < 0.01 cases/100 000 (essentially zero) for the same age group today. |
| **Deaths & permanent disability** | ~ 15 % of paralytic cases resulted in death; many survivors had permanent muscle weakness or respiratory failure requiring ventilators. | < 1 death in the past 40 years; virtually no new cases of permanent paralysis. |
| **Economic & societal impact** | **$1 billion+** in health‑care costs (hospitalisation, long‑term care) in the 1950s; families often lost a primary earner; large‑scale quarantine and school closures were common. | Savings of **billions of dollars** in avoided hospital care, long‑term disability benefits, and parental work loss; no need for mass quarantine. |
| **Geographic spread** | Outbreaks occurred in **every state** annually; polio was the leading cause of childhood paralysis. | The U.S. has been **polio‑free** for > 40 years; only a handful of vaccine‑derived cases linked to the oral vaccine (now discontinued in the U.S.) have been identified, all in people who received the vaccine abroad. |

#### How the vaccine achieved this decline

1. **High coverage quickly achieved herd immunity** – By 1962, > 90 % of U.S. children had received at least one dose of IPV/OPV, driving the effective reproduction number (Rₑ) below 1.
2. **Two‑dose primary series + boosters** – The schedule (3‑dose primary series at 2, 4, 6 months, plus a booster at 4–6 years) created durable immunity that persisted into adulthood.
3. **Surveillance and rapid response** – The CDC’s Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) surveillance network detected any residual cases, prompting immediate public‑health action (e.g., targeted “catch‑up” campaigns).

#### Global context (for perspective)

| Region | Pre‑vaccine (circa 1950) | Post‑vaccine (2020‑2023) |
|--------|--------------------------|--------------------------|
| Worldwide annual paralytic cases | **≈ 350 000** | **≈ 30** (all in a handful of countries where wild poliovirus still circulates) |
| Countries ever reporting wild polio | **125** | **3** (Afghanistan, Pakistan, and a few isolated pockets in Africa that were cleared in 2023) |

> **Key takeaway:** The **inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV)** – given to all U.S. infants as part of the routine schedule – is directly responsible for the **near‑elimination of paralytic polio** in the United States and for the dramatic global decline from hundreds of thousands of cases per year to a handful of cases today.
